_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: storage tank, hoses, valves and piping

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Facility Policy
The management and employes of the Ottawa Cooperative Association are committed
to the prevention of any accidental release of Anhydrous Ammonia. If an accidental
release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department and or
other authorities, to mitigate and minimize the impacts of the release to the people
and the environment.

2. Facility Information
Our plant consists of one Amhydrous Ammonia storage tank.  Our maximum inventory report is on file in the compliance manual and has been shared with the local emergency responders to use for training and pre planning.

3. Worst case scenario and alternate releaswe scenario
The worst case and the alternate release scenarios have been evalusted and shared
with our local first responders as part of and on-going training program. More
importantly our employees have been trained in their respective emergency actions,
including the emergency meeting place and each of their individual responsibilities
regarding an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.

4.Accidental Release Program
The facility strives for compliance with the provisions of the US Occupational Safety and Health
Administration, 29 CFR19140.11, Storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia. This facility
is also in compliance with the provisions of the Kansas Fertilizer Law. The OHSA Standard
is refenenced in the RMP registration form in section 8.3(b)
There are many hazards associated with anhydrous ammonia. We require that each employee
that loads ammonia be trained every three years at a state sponsered training school.
And yearly trained in operating and safety proceedures. And a given ammonia plant.
All employees are trained to inspect the ammonia plant before filling procedures and before use do a visual inspection of all hoses and valves to make sure there has not been a failure of equipment since the last time it was used. Employees are reminded to follow start up procedures before filling and during fill

ing of nurse tanks.

5. Five year accident history
There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that
have caused any deaths, injuries or significant property damage at the facility, not to our knowledge has there been any accidental releases resulting in off site deaths, injuries,evacuations, property damage or envirnomental damage.

6. Emergency action plan
A. A written action plan, in acccordance with OSHA standard 29 cfr 1910-38

B. Provided state and local authorities with the emergency planning and community
right to know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA)

C. If a large release of anhydrous ammonia takes place at the facility, the required
response action is to evacuate the area of the spill and call 911 and all applicable
emergency response numbers.
1. Wiithin 15 minutes of determing the amount of the release would be over 100 pounds
the emergency coordinator will notify: The National Response Center (800-424-8802)

2. Within 24 hours of determining the amount of release would effect the envirnoment
the emergency coordinator will notify: Kansas Bureau of Environmental Remediation
(785-296-1679) or after normal hours (785-296-0614) and the Kansas Department of
of Emergency Management (785-296-3176) and in all cases the Kansas Department
of Agriculture (785-296-3301).

3. Planned changes to improve safety
Safety improvement is an ongoing process at the facility, perodic evaluations are
performed to assess the conditions of the facility, there are no additional
specific safety recommendations regarding storage or use of Anhydrous Ammonia
for implementation at this time.
